results.description: Learn about ethylene oxide, which can raise your risk of lymphoma and leukemia. Exposure may occur through industrial emissions, tobacco smoke, and the use of products sterilized with ethylene oxide, such as certain medical products or cosmetics.
results.title: Ethylene Oxide - Cancer-Causing Substances - National Cancer Institute

results.description: This page lists substances that may cause or contribute to the development of cancer, depending on amount of exposure, an individual's genetic background, and other factors.
results.title: Cancer-Causing Substances in the Environment - National Cancer Institute

results.description: A fact sheet that lists some of the cancer-causing chemicals in tobacco smoke and describes the health problems caused by cigarette smoking and the benefits of quitting.
results.title: Harms of Cigarette Smoking and Health Benefits of Quitting - National Cancer Institute

results.description: Metastatic tumor cells are particularly sensitive to oxidative stress, and antioxidant supplementation increases their ability to grow and metastasize.
results.title: Antioxidants Accelerate the Growth and Invasiveness of Tumors in Mice - National Cancer Institute

results.description: Aberrant expression of an inflammatory protein, nitric oxide synthase 2 (NOS2), may enhance the progression and metastasis of an aggressive and less common form of breast cancer, known as the estrogen receptor-negative type of disease.
results.title: Study in mice shows that an aggressive type of breast cancer is linked to an inflammatory protein - National Cancer Institute

results.description: New research is revealing the mechanisms regulating the Warburg effect, the balance between oxidation and glycolysis of glucose in cancer cells.
results.title: vander-heiden-warburg-effect - National Cancer Institute
